Unravel the surface active sites on Cu/MgLaO solid base catalyst by DRIFT spectroscopy and adsorption techniques for the synthesis of triazoles by click reaction This paper is dedicated to our beloved teacher Dr P Kanta Rao on the occasion of his 80th birthday. Vishali Bilakanti a Venu Boosa a Naresh Gutta a Vijay Kumar Velisoju a Sreedhar Inkollu b Venugopal Akula a ⁎ a Catalysis and Fine Chemicals Division, CSIR – Indian Institute of Chemical Technology, Tarnaka, Hyderabad, Telangana State, 500 007, India Catalysis and Fine Chemicals Division CSIR – Indian Institute of Chemical Technology Tarnaka Hyderabad Telangana State 500 007 India Catalysis and Fine Chemicals Division, CSIR – Indian Institute of Chemical Technology, Tarnaka, Hyderabad, Telangana State - 500 007, India. b Department of Chemical Engineering, BITS Pilani Hyderabad Campus, Hyderabad 500 078, Telangana State, India Department of Chemical Engineering BITS Pilani Hyderabad Campus Hyderabad Telangana State 500 078 India Department of Chemical Engineering, BITS Pilani Hyderabad Campus, Hyderabad 500 078, Telangana State, India. ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform (DRIFT) spectroscopy explored the surface basicity of Cu supported on MgO, La2O3 and MgLaO catalysts in the Click reaction of aryl alkyne and aryl azide for the synthesis of substituted triazoles by using formic acid as a probe. Ionic copper in combination with surface basic sites played a prominent role for a high rate of the desired product over 5 wt%Cu/MgLaO catalyst at 70 °C and water as solvent in the absence of a base. A structure-activity correlation established for the Click reaction using in situ DRIFT spectroscopy and based on the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area, X-ray diffraction (XRD), H2- temperature programmed reduction (TPR), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), N2O titration and temperature programmed desorption (TPD) of CO2 analyses plausible reaction mechanism was established. The bulk and surface properties of the recovered 5 wt%Cu/MgLaO revealed that the catalyst was stable even after 4 recycles. Keywords Click reaction Copper Basicity MgLaO FA-DRIFTS Introduction Biological active heterocyclic moieties, particularly, substituted 1,2,3-Triazoles synthesis using Cu(I) - catalyst is a significant method for the formation of privileged medicinal scaffolds, possesses anticancer, antimicrobial, anti-inflammatory, antiparasitic, anti malarial, antiviral and anti-HIV, antitubercular and antimycobacterial activity etc [1–8]. Ruthenium(II)- and copper(I)- mediated azide-alkyne cycloaddition reactions have gained much attention because of their regioselectivity and reliable triazole-forming property [9]. The tricyclic heterocyclic compounds play a vital role in medicinal chemistry with different applications e.g. phenothiazine (PTZ) and its derivatives showed various biological activities such as psychotropic, antitumor, antihelminthic and pharmacological properties and N-substituted PTZ derivatives are identified as potential to clinical research [10–12]. The other applications of PTZ derivatives are photosensitizers in the photodynamic therapy [13]. Phenoxazine (POZ) and its N-substituted POZs are identified as modulators of multidrug-resistant tuberculosis and as potent specific inhibitors of Akt signalling [14,15]. The carbazole derivatives were known to exhibit antitubercular, antimycobacterial activities [16]. One-pot synthesis of triazole substituted hetero cyclic compounds using multicomponent with less number of synthetic steps is always desirable. Development of solid acid-base catalyst for improved synthetic methods for the Click chemistry remains an important research area. The challenges associated with Click reaction are the synthesize combination of tricyclic substituted triazoles over solid heterogeneous recyclable catalysts as it would avoid toxic or environmentally hazardous solvents. It is also a known fact that the studies pertaining to structure-activity relationship using adsorption and spectroscopic techniques are scanty especially in the area of click chemistry, thus the studies owing to surface properties of the solid base catalysts are required [17,18]. The synthesis of new tricyclic hetero aromatic 1,2,3-triazoles process was systematically investigated with a recyclable copper catalyst via Click chemistry (Scheme 1 ). During the recent past, several homogeneous and heterogeneous Cu catalysts were established for the Click reaction [19–23]. Non Cu catalysts are also employed toward the Click reaction using expensive ruthenium hydride complex, nanoporous Au/TiO2 catalyst, RuH2(CO)-(PPh3)3, and cheaper supported zinc/charcoal catalysts and Ag-Al2O3@Fe2O3 catalyst [24–28]. Gholinejad et al, used CuNPs@agarose as catalyst and mesoporous silica supported copper and MOF-supported copper catalysts were also reported for the Click reaction [29–31]. Dufaud et al reported highly active Cu(II)phen@SBA-15 catalyst under mild reaction conditions towards Click reaction with high yields [32]. Recently, Singh et al explored mono- and dinuclear heteroleptic Cu(I) dithio- PPh3 catalytic systems for azide and alkyne cycloaddition reaction to synthesize the glycoconjugate triazoles [33]. The mixed oxide of MgO-La2O3 is known to possess basicity which has been explored for -C–H activation and also for cyanation of C–H bond [34]. Previously, magnesium-lanthanum mixed oxide supported nickel, ruthenium and palladium catalysts were explored in Kumada coupling and levulinic acid was selectively hydrogenated to γ-valerolactone, Suzuki-Miyaura cross-coupling and Sonogashira coupling reactions [35–39]. The application of solid base catalyst for various organic transformations such as hydrogenation reactions, organic carbonates and Michael addition reactions were reported recently [40–42]. A good work from Yamaguchi et al on the catalytic performance of Cu-hydroxide supported on TiO2 for the Click reaction is reported [21]. In the view of environmental and economical aspects, identification of surface active sites is utmost important particularly to avoid the by-product formation. The present study showcases the nature of surface active sites for the synthesis of triazoles by Click reaction. Hence, a detailed investigation is carried out in order to identify the surface active sites by the in-situ probe adsorbed diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform (DRIFT) spectroscopy in conjunction with N2O pulse titration technique, one of the efficient tools for elucidating the surface reaction mechanism under the reaction conditions adopted [43–45]. Experimental section Materials The required chemicals particularly phenothiazine, phenoxazine, carbazole, propargyl bromide, tert-butyl nitrite and trimethylsilyl azide were acquired by Sigma-Aldrich. All the solvents used in this work were purified by standard procedures. Remaining used chemicals in this work were analytical grade. Methodology adopted for the Synthesis of 1,2,3-triazoles Substituted alkynes and azides synthetic procedures were adopted from the previous literature and the detailed procedure has been inserted in supporting information [46–49]. For the construction of 1,4-di substituted 1,2,3-triazoles, 5 wt%Cu/MgLaO (50 mg) catalyst and an aryl alkyne (1 mmol), aryl azide (1 mmol) were taken in RB flask in H2O (4 mL) solvent medium. The mixture was refluxed at 70 °C for 1 h. The catalyst was removed by filtration when the reaction was completed and washed with H2O followed by drying under vacuum and stored for a new run. The filtrate was thoroughly washed with EA and then subjected to rotor-evaporator in order to remove the solvent. The crude was purified using column chromatography to get the product. The pure compounds are analysed by 1H, 13C NMR spectral data. Preparation of catalysts By using magnesium and/or lanthanum nitrates in co-precipitation method, the MgLaO mixed oxide, MgO and La2O3 were prepared with Mg:La = 3:1 mol ratio (for MgLaO support) of magnesium and lanthanum nitrates respectively [35]. The detailed procedure for the synthesis of MgO, La2O3 and MgLaO supports by co-precipitation method is also given in supporting information. All the supported Cu catalysts were synthesized using wet impregnation technique. The detailed procedure was similar to what has been reported by us earlier and is also given in supporting information under experimental section [50]. Results Catalytic activity measurements The optimization studies were performed, employing the 9-(prop-2-yn-1-yl)-9H-carbazole (terminal alkyne) and 1-Azido-4-nitrobenzene (azide) in a one-pot Cu-catalyzed coupling reaction and cycloaddition as model substrates. As can be seen from Table 1 ; the 2.5 wt%Cu supported on silica (a neutral support) and/or on a weak solid base such as Al2O3 afforded very lower yields of up to 19 and 31% after 3 h (Table 1; entry 1, 2) in DIPEA (as base) and DMSO as a solvent. Several experiments were performed over Cu impregnated on different supports using different solvents; and the obtained yields are given in Table 1. Using 2.5 wt%Cu/MgO and 2.5 wt%Cu/La2O3 catalysts, DIPEA as base, DMSO as solvent at 100 °C, the obtained yields towards the desired product were in 48 and 60% respectively (Table 1; entry 3, 4). When the 2.5 wt%Cu/MgLaO catalyst was examined; it showed about 47% yield using DIPEA (as base) and DMF (as solvent) (Table 1; entry 5), whereas, an improved yield ̴ 68%was obtained (Table 1; entry 6) in DMSO as solvent. The reaction was performed for 3 h and 1 h using mixture of solvents (DMF:H2O); H2O alone as solvent and K2CO3 as a base, the desired product was formed in about ˜73 and ˜76% yields (Table 1; entry 7, 8). To our delight, about 85% of desired product was obtained within 1 h over 2.5 wt%Cu/MgLaO catalyst using H2O as solvent and without base (Table 1; entry 10). This reaction undergone excellently in water while compared with any other solvent and what is noticeable is that in the absence of a base [51]. When different Cu loaded MgLaO catalysts were examined; the 5 wt%Cu/MgLaO demonstrated better yield (˜98%) compared to other loadings (Table 1; entries 9, 11, 12 and 13). Upon testing the 5 wt%Cu/MgO, 5 wt%Cu/La2O3 catalyst using H2O as solvent and without base; the product yield (Table 1; entries 14, 15) was still lower compared to 5 wt%Cu/MgLaO (Table 1; entry 11). Substrate scope for Click reaction over 5.0 wt%Cu/MgLaO catalyst Under the optimized conditions, several substrates were examined over 5 wt%Cu/MgLaO catalyst in water as solvent at 70 °C for the triazole synthesis using an array of various alkynes, azides and the yields are summarized in Fig. 1 . The carbazole, phenoxazine, phenothiazines are the organic compounds which would possess electron-donor properties [52,53]. Using 1-azido-4-methoxybenzene with terminal alkynes (9-(prop-2-yn-1-yl)-9H-carbazole, 10-(prop-2-yn-1-yl)-10H-phenoxazine, 10-(prop-2-yn-1-yl)-10H-phenothiazine), delivered the product with good yields 95, 94 and 94% respectively (Fig. 1; 3a, 3b, 3c). In contrast to this electron-deficient group substituted 1-Azido-4-nitrobenzene produced high yields of about ˜98, 98 and 98% respectively than with the 1-azido-4-methoxybenzene, and the obtained results are well supported with the previous literature (Fig. 1; 3d, 3e, 3f) [54]. The reaction is sensitive to 3-Azido-9H-fluorene, which showed ˜94, 93 and 93% was obtained (Fig. 1; 3 g, 3 h, 3i). Using 7-azido-4-(trifluoromethyl)-2H-chromen-2-one as azide; the reaction performed smoothly to the expected desired products of about 95, 96 and 95% yields respectively (Fig. 1; 3 j, 3k, 3 l). With 6-azido-2-methylbenzo[d]thiazole, the corresponding products were obtained in 90, 91 and 92% yield (Fig. 1; 3 m, 3n and 3o). When 2-azidoanthracene was employed, the isolated product yields are 91, 90 and 92% respectively (Fig. 1; 3p, 3q, 3 r). X-ray diffraction (XRD) The XRD analyses of all the catalysts showed the presence of their respective phase (Fig. 2 ) and all the phases present in the catalysts is confirmed with standard ICDD data. The XRD pattern of 5 wt%Cu/MgO showed diffraction lines at 2θ = 37°, 42.8° and 62.2° (ICDD # 4–829) that are due to MgO phase. The 5 wt%Cu/La2O3 (Fig. 2) exhibited characteristic diffraction lines of La2O3 phase (ICDD # 24-0554) at 2θ = 27.9°, 30.6°, 44.2°, 47.5°, 57.2° and 52.8°. The XRD profiles of 5 wt%Cu/MgLaO sample showed the diffraction peaks at 2θ = 29.55°, 22.02°, 26.27°, 13.1°, 30.51°, 33.46°, 44.55°, 50.42° and 56.95° which are attributed to La2O2(CO3) phase [ICDD # 23-0435]. In addition, the reflection lines due to CuO phase is noticed in all the samples at 2θ = 35.40° and 38.02° (ICDD # 45-0937). The reflections of 5 wt%Cu/MgLaO catalyst in fresh and spent form, revealed no significant differences, indicating its stability under the adopted reaction conditions. The XRD analysis of different copper loadings on MgLaO samples is presented in the Figure S1 and the results confirmed the presence of phases due to CuO and La2O2(CO3) phases. In the comparative analysis, the XRD patterns showed an increase in the CuO diffraction line intensity with the increase in copper loading on the support (Figure S1). Physico-chemical properties of the catalysts The N2-physisorption of MgO, La2O3 and MgLaO supports showed surface area 39.8, 40.7 and 36.6 m2 g−1 respectively and copper loaded MgO, La2O3 and MgLaO samples showed a significant reduction in surface area after copper impregnation on to the support materials (Table 2 ). This is mainly due to support pores were blocked by the Cu particles; as a result, the surface area is decreased. The obtained results are in accordance with the copper metal surface area, which is obtained from in the N2O uptakes, where no major changes are observed. The N2-physisorption at −196 °C showed that the bare MgLaO had relatively high surface area compared to Cu/MgLaO samples, which is mainly due to the support pores were blocked with the Cu particles; as a result, the surface area is decreased. Using the pulse N2O titration (Table 3 ) it has been concluded that a 5 wt%Cu loaded sample exhibited a higher copper metal surface area than the other loadings. H2-temperature programmed reduction (TPR) analysis The H2- temperature programmed reduction analysis of copper supported on MgO, La2O3 and MgLaO catalysts are showed in Fig. 3 and H2 uptakes are presented in Table 2. The reduction profile provides information about metal-support interaction and the extent of metal oxide reduction on the support. It can be seen that the peaks were broad and resolved, indicating the formation of two type’s Cu species on the catalyst. The 5 wt%Cu/MgLaO catalyst, showed main reduction peak at 314 °C is probably ascribed to CuO species are finely dispersed on the support and the shoulder at 397 °C (Fig. 3a), is due to reduction of bulk copper oxide species [18]. In case of 5 wt%Cu/La2O3 catalyst, showed relatively broad peak and shifted to high temperature (Fig. 3b) region. A similar trend is observed in case of 5 wt%Cu/MgO sample typically reduced in two stages, lower temperature peak at 355 °C, which is probably due to the fine dispersion of copper oxide particles on the MgO support (Fig. 3c), whereas the high temperature peak at 430 °C is mainly attributed to the presence of larger copper clusters, which are strongly interacted with MgO [55]. No significant changes in H2 uptake is observed in all the catalysts due to fixed quantity of Cu present on the support explaining the bulk property of the H2-TPR analysis (Table 2). CO2- temperature programmed desorption (TPD) analysis In order to rationalize the role of surface basicity for the Click reaction; the Cu supported on MgO, La2O3 and MgLaO samples were analyzed by TPD of CO2 and the results are reported in Fig. 4 . In general, weak basic sites appear below 200 °C and peaks around 200-400 °C represents the moderate basic sites and the peak at and above 400 °C corresponds to catalyst surface with strong basic sites [56]. The CO2-TPD pattern of copper on MgO shows 3 main peaks at 174, 296 and 431 °C which are corresponding to weak, moderate and strong basic sites (Fig. 4a). A high proportion of moderate basic sites are observed over both 5 wt%Cu/MgO and 5 wt%Cu/La2O3 samples (Fig. 4a and 4b). The TPD of CO2 profile of 5 wt%Cu/MgLaO (Fig. 4c) also showed 3 peaks ascribed to weak (174 °C) moderate (317 °C) and a very strong signal at 444 °C with a shoulder (at 525 °C) due to strong basic sites. Finally, the above mentioned results revealed the 5 wt%Cu/MgLaO exhibited strong basic sites compared to the MgO, La2O3 supported Cu catalysts (Table 2). Formic acid adsorbed DRIFTS studies The surface basic properties of the catalysts are also studied using in situ formic acid (FA) adsorbed DRIFT spectroscopy (Fig. 5 ). The obtained results demonstrated that all these catalysts possessed higher basicity as a result of the surface species such as O2− and OH- (MgO, La2O3, MgLaO and surface hydroxyl groups). The COOH adsorbed DRIFT spectra showed surface basic sites strongly interacting with FA are due to the stretching and bending vibrational modes of surface formate (both −CH and −COO) and carbonate species over MgO, La2O3 and MgLaO supports. However, MgO and La2O3 samples displayed low intense vibrational bands, which are arising from interaction of catalyst surface with formate (COO−) and −CH species. On the other hand the La2O3, MgLaO supports possesses comparatively strong band at 1590 cm-1 owing to νs COO and δCH, νs COO band at 1348 cm-1 (Fig. 5A). The band at 1664 cm-1 indicates the associative adsorption of FA on the catalyst surface [43,17]. After Cu impregnation on supports (MgO, La2O3 and MgLaO) no significant difference in the peak position but slightly relative increase in peak intensities is observed (Fig. 5B), thus suggesting that the quantity of formate species was higher. The formic acid adsorbed spectra over 5 wt%Cu/MgLaO at different temperatures were recorded. The bands appeared at 1590, 1350 and 1664 cm−1 showed decline in intensity with the raise of temperature from 125- 200 °C (Fig. 5C). The weak band at 1746 cm-1 for Cu/MgLaO but not observed for support (MgLaO) (Fig. 5A), may be ascribed to adsorbed formic acid molecules ligated to the surface copper. The temperature was increased from 125–200 °C of 5 wt%Cu/MgO and 5 wt%Cu/La2O3 the band intensity was decreased (Figure S2). FA interaction with basic sites on the catalyst surface can be illustrated as follows: (1) Mn+ ̶ O2– + HCOOH → Mn+ ̶ OH– + HCOO– (Mn+ = Cu) (2) Mn+ ̶ OH– + HCOOH →Mn+ ̶ H2O + HCOO– (Mn+ = Cu) In the comparative analysis, the TPD of CO2 results indicated strong basic sites on Cu/MgLaO as compared to its counterparts MgO and La2O3. In addition, the quantitative analysis of the 1590 and 1350 cm−1 bands revealed high proportion (high ratio of I1590/I1350) of strong basic sites over 5 wt%Cu/MgLaO as compared to other supports (Table 2). This further explains the synergy between Mg and La with particular composition of the respective metals leads to the generation of surface with strong basic sites, which is also well correlated with the reported data [41]. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) analysis TEM analysis of the fresh and spent (after 4 cycles) of 5 wt%Cu/MgLaO catalysts are displayed in Figure S4. Fresh catalyst showed the average Cu particle size of 20 nm and spent catalyst had the size of 22 nm. Moreover, both fresh and spent samples showed random distribution of spherical copper particles on the catalyst support. Finally, it can be concluded that the particle size and morphology of copper particles are not much varied for the fresh and used catalysts, indicating the stability of 5 wt%Cu/MgLaO during the course of reaction. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) In near surface region fresh catalyst was analysed by XPS to identify the copper oxidation state. The binding energies 933.3 eV and 953.3 eV conformed presence of CuO species on catalyst surface (Fig. 6 ) [57]. The XPS of the spent catalyst showed Cu 2p3/2 and Cu 2p1/2 signals at 933.3 eV and 953.1 eV respectively. The binding energy 533.2 eV is due to presence of oxygen on the catalyst surface (Figure S5). No evidence of shift in Cu2+ signals in the recovered catalyst, emphasizing the robustness of the catalyst surface even after 4 cycles. Discussion The surface basic properties obtained from formic acid adsorbed DRIFT spectra (Fig. 5) showed strong basicity over the Cu supported on MgLaO catalyst, this observation is also supported by the CO2-TPD analysis (Fig. 4). Thus, these results emphasize the role of surface basic sites on the Click reaction where 5 wt%Cu/MgLaO was found to display superior activity compared to the individual MgO and La2O3 supported Cu catalyst. It is worth noticing that there exists a direct correlation between the surface basicity (the intensity ratio of FA adsorbed DRIFTS bands; I1590/I1350) and rate of formation of desired product (Fig. 7 ). As mentioned earlier, the 5 wt%Cu/MgLaO catalyst surface has strong basic sites, which is one of key reasons for its high catalytic performance in Click reaction compared to Cu supported on MgO and La2O3 catalysts. In addition to basic sites, the copper loadings on MgLaO also played a key role on the product yield. It is interesting to note that with increase in the copper loading up to 5 wt% desired product formation rate increased where highest rate and Cu metal surface area was observed (Table 3). Beyond 5 wt%Cu on MgLaO, no significant differences in the product rate and Cu surface area is observed. These results therefore clearly indicate that the activity towards the desired triazole product is dependent on surface copper species in conjunction with the strong basic sites as exemplified by N2O titration and formic acid adsorbed DRIFTS respectively (Fig. 8 ). Based on the aforementioned bulk and surface properties of the 5 wt%Cu/MgLaO catalyst, a plausible reaction mechanism for Click reaction of aryl alkyne and aryl azide to produce substituted triazole is presented in Scheme 2 [58]. Initially, basic sites were deprotonated the terminal alkyne which coordinates with the copper centre to form copper(I) acetylide in the next step. Subsequently in the transition state, a second copper(II) site interacts with the sp carbon atoms of the Cu(I)-acetylide, which results in the enhancement in the reactivity by decreasing the electron density on the Cu(I)-acetylide followed by the addition of azide produced a dicuprate complex. In next step, the C–N bond is formed and generating a six-membered ring intermediate. This intermediate undergo reductive elimination to produce 5-cuprated triazole intermediate and subsequently the intermediate undergo protonation gives rise to desired product and regenerates the copper(II) species on the catalyst surface. Recyclability studies The feasibility of repeated use of 5 wt%Cu supported on MgLaO catalyst was examined for the Click reaction. By using (9-(prop-2-yn-1-yl)-9H-carbazole and 1-Azido-4-nitrobenzene as model substrates on a 1.5 mmol scale at 70 °C and water as solvent (Figure S6). Cu species are not leached from the catalyst (after 4th cycle) was confirmed by XRD and XPS analyses of fresh and spent catalysts. The AAS analysis of the 5 wt%Cu/MgLaO fresh and spent (recovered after forth cycle) catalyst displayed 4.97% and 4.97% of Cu, respectively. Above results revealed that there is not much significant change was observed for spent catalyst in terms of catalyst structure (surface and/or bulk), indicating the robust nature of 5 wt%Cu/MgLaO in click reaction. Finally, it is concluded that a 5 wt%Cu loaded on MgLaO showed better activity towards Click reaction under moderate reaction conditions (up to 4 recycles) than the other supports. The surface characteristics of the 5 wt%Cu/MgLaO catalyst was estimated using N2-sorption analysis; formic acid adsorbed FT-IR studies, powder XRD, H2- TPR, TPD of CO2, N2O titration, SEM-EDX, TEM and XPS in order to rationalize the higher activity for Click reaction. Conclusions The Cu/MgLaO has been identified for the synthesis of tricyclic 1,4-disubstituted 1,2,3- triazoles regioselectively, as one of the simplest, efficient, ecologically friendly and robust catalytic system developed in the absence of additives such as stabilizing ligands, reducing agents and also any base. In this reaction, carbazole, phenothiazine, phenoxazine substituted triazole molecules were synthesized in high to very good yields. The method developed in this study are highly atom economic that use a recyclable supported non-noble metal catalyst (i.e. Cu/MgLaO) with shortened reaction time of 1 h exhibiting 98% yield of desired triazole product at 70 °C. This method provides not only the designing of newer molecules and also a useful approach for the development of novel biologically active hetero aromatic compounds. The HCOOH adsorbed DRIFT spectra and TPD of CO2 explored the strong basic sites role in Click reaction. The triazole yield was drastically improved when the copper loading was increased up to 5 wt%, while further increase in the Cu loading did not show significant improvement. Combination of copper sites with strong basic sites is responsible for this reaction, which is established from the N2O titration and DRIFTS data. The formic acid adsorbed DRIFT spectra demonstrated the presence of strong basicity on the Cu/MgLaO surface compared to MgO and La2O3 supports. Presence of H2O had a beneficial role on the formation of the desired product. These results also proved that an appropriate proportion of basic sites in the catalysts were key and essential in determining the high yields of the triazole product. Acknowledgements B. coredata.dc:description: Diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform (DRIFT) spectroscopy explored the surface basicity of Cu supported on MgO, La2O3 and MgLaO catalysts in the Click reaction of aryl alkyne and aryl azide for the synthesis of substituted triazoles by using formic acid as a probe. Ionic copper in combination with surface basic sites played a prominent role for a high rate of the desired product over 5 wt%Cu/MgLaO catalyst at 70 °C and water as solvent in the absence of a base. A structure-activity correlation established for the Click reaction using in situ DRIFT spectroscopy and based on the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area, X-ray diffraction (XRD), H2- temperature programmed reduction (TPR), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), N2O titration and temperature programmed desorption (TPD) of CO2 analyses plausible reaction mechanism was established. The bulk and surface properties of the recovered 5 wt%Cu/MgLaO revealed that the catalyst was stable even after 4 recycles.
coredata.dc:title: Unravel the surface active sites on Cu/MgLaO solid base catalyst by DRIFT spectroscopy and adsorption techniques for the synthesis of triazoles by click reaction
